Award.AwardTitle: Growth Control by Hippo Signaling in Drosophila
Award.AbstractNarration:
Growth inhibitory signaling mediated by the Hippo pathway provides an important regulatory mechanism for tissue growth and organ size control in animal development. Loss of Hippo signaling leads to tissue overgrowth and aberrant organ size in animals like fruit flies and mice. Previous studies have identified several key components in this pathway. A central question in this field is how Hippo signaling is activated by upstream components to control tissue growth and organ size. Also, it is not clear how cellular growth is regulated by Hippo signaling. This project will address these questions with molecular and genetic approaches investigating the role of upstream molecules, Expanded, Merlin and Sav, in Hippo membrane localization and activation. Itwill also test a hypothesis that Hippo signaling negatively regulates cellular growth by blocking insulin receptor signaling activities. Hippo membrane localization is expected to be a key step for its activation. Studies on Hippo signaling shall advance our knowledge of how tissue growth and organ size are controlled in animal development. Moreover, this research project provides great opportunities to promote teaching, training, and learning for graduate and undergraduate students.
During summers, high school students from an outreach program will come to Dr. Lai's laboratory to gain research experience in developmental biology and genetics. To disseminate research results, the Lai laboratory will publish its work in a timely fashion, regularly attend conferences and give talks in local schools and other institutions to enhance scientific understanding by the community and society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a developing multicellular organism, cells have to not only properly responding to signals that stimulate the increase of cell numbers but also being sensitive to signals that limit tissue growth.  Growth inhibitory signaling mediated by the Hippo pathway provides an important regulatory mechanism for tissue growth and organ size control in animal development.  Loss of Hippo signaling leads to tissue overgrowth and aberrant organ size in animals like fruit flies and mice.  Previous studies have identified key components that include two protein kinases Hippo and Warts, a Warts kinase co-activator Mats, and a scaffold protein Sav.  A central question in this field is how Hippo signaling is activated by upstream components to control tissue growth and organ size.  Also, it is not clear how cell size is regulated by Hippo signaling.  To address these questions, we have taken molecular and genetic approaches to investigate the role of upstream molecules, Expanded, Merlin and Sav, in Hippo membrane localization and activation.  We have also tested a hypothesis that Hippo signaling negatively regulates cellular growth by blocking insulin receptor/Akt signaling activities.  Through this project, we have learned that Hippo and Akt signaling pathways are coordinated to regulate tissue growth and organ size.  In particular, tissue overgrowth induced by the loss of Hippo growth inhibitory signaling is critically dependent on Akt signaling activity.  Moreover, we have found that Hpo kinase dimerization near the plasma membrane is an important step for Hpo kinase activation to mediate growth inhibition in developing tissues.  As the Hippo pathway is evolutionarily conserved, what we have learned using the Drosophila model could help our understanding of developmental mechanisms in vertebrate animals including humans.  Moreover, this research project has provided training opportunities for six PhD students (including five females), six undergraduate students, and four underrepresented high school students from the Upward Bound Math and science (UBMS) Program.  All the graduate students and some undergraduate students have attended professional research conferences to report their work and learn from other scientists through direct communications.  During this period, we have published four research articles directly related to this project.
